title: French President Macron Condemns Vandalism of Art Piece â€˜Promoting Pedophiliaâ€™
text:
French President Emmanuel Macron raised eyebrows this week after condemning the vandalism of a vile art piece accused of promoting pedophilia.
â€œOn this May 8, when we celebrate the victory of freedom, I condemn the act of vandalism committed yesterday at the Palais de Tokyo,â€ Macron tweeted Monday. â€œTo attack a work is to attack our values. In France, art is always free and respect for cultural creation is guaranteed.â€
â€œItâ€™s a direct attack on freedom of expression, which is quite serious,â€ added French Minister of Culture Rima Abdul Malak.
On Sunday, an elderly vandal spray-painted artist Miriam Cahnâ€™s painting fuck abstraction! inside the Palais de Tokyo gallery in Paris.
â€œThe perpetrator of the spray paint attack, described as elderly according to a source close to the case, was â€˜unhappy with the sexual portrayal of a child and an adult presented in the paintingâ€™ but was not affiliated with an activist group,â€ reported the Times of Israel.
The piece features what appears to be a child in bondage performing fellatio on a male figure.
En ce 8 mai, oÃ¹ nous cÃ©lÃ©brons la victoire de la libertÃ©, jâ€™avoue avoir un petit faible pour la nouvelle version de â€œFuck Abstractionâ€ qui incarne parfaitement la libertÃ© de dire non Ã  la pÃ©docriminalitÃ©. pic.twitter.com/SqDuUWKfip
The piece, which has been on display since February, was condemned in March by the group Association Juristes de lâ€™Enfance (Lawyers for Children), who argued the painting should be taken down for â€œrepresenting fellatio imposed by a naked man erect on a tied up child.â€
Cahn meanwhile maintained her painting depicts war crimes in Ukraine. 
â€œThisÂ painting deals with the way in which sexuality is used as a weapon of war, as a crime against humanity,â€Â she claimed.Â  Â 
Lawyers for Children sued to have the painting removed â€œon the grounds that French law forbids the exhibition of pornographic representations of minors,â€ according to ArtNet.com, however, a judge dismissed the lawsuit in late March. 
The decision was later upheld by the French Supreme Court in April, noting measures had been taken to deter minors from accessing the painting, and that panels leading to the painting helped clarify Cahnâ€™s intended meaning, which she claimed was to denounce rapes in Ukraine.
Cultural Minister Malak celebrated the fact the painting effectively depicting child rape would now legally be allowed to continue to hang in the museum.
â€œIn agreement with the artist, the Palais de Tokyo will continue to present the painting and the exposition,â€ Malak said, â€œwith traces of the damage until the end of the season, May 14.â€
The Times of Israel notes Cahn has previously used her work for activism:
â€œCahn has also carried out her own protest in the art world. In 2021, she decided toÂ pull her paintingsÂ from one of Switzerlandâ€™s largest art museums over its decision to permanently house a controversial Nazi-era collection.â€
While President Macron was quick to condemn vandalism of the disgusting art piece, he apparently has not issued similar statements in regards to Extinction Rebellion climate change activists vandalizing historical art in other French museums like the Louvre or the Museum of Modern Art.

title: FBI REFUSES to Give Congress Informant File Alleging Biden Took Bribes as Vice President
text:
The Federal Bureau of Investigations defied a legally binding subpoena issued by Congress requiring it turn over an informant file alleging Joe Biden took bribes as Vice President.
House Oversight Committee Chairman James Comer (R-Ky.)Â issued the subpoena last week requiring the FBI hand over the file by Wednesday, May 10.
Instead of turning over the file, the FBI responded with a letter contending it will continue to withhold it from Congress to protect â€œconfidential human sources.â€
â€œInformation from confidential human sources is unverifiedÂ and, by definition, incomplete,â€ wroteÂ FBI acting assistant director for congressional affairs Christopher Dunham.
â€œAs is clear from the name itself, confidentiality is definitional to the FBIâ€™s ConfidentialÂ Human Source program,â€Â Dunham wrote.Â â€œConfidential human sources often provide information to the FBI atÂ great risk to themselves and their loved ones. The information they provide also can createÂ significant risks to others who may be referenced in their reporting.â€
â€œWeâ€¦hope this helps youÂ understand that keeping this kind of source information free from the perception or reality ofÂ improper influence â€” and preventing the redirection of this information for non-law enforcementÂ or non-intelligence uses â€” is necessary for the FBIâ€™s effective execution of our law enforcementÂ and national security responsibilities,â€ he added.
Rep. Comer blasted the FBI for stonewalling on the file.
â€œItâ€™s clear from the FBIâ€™s response that the unclassified record the Oversight Committee subpoenaed exists, but they are refusing to provide it to the Committee,â€ Comer told the New York Post.
â€œWeâ€™ve asked the FBI to not only provide this record, but to also inform us what it did to investigate these allegations,â€ he added. â€œThe FBI has failed to do both. The FBIâ€™s position is â€˜trust, but you arenâ€™t allowed to verify.â€™ That is unacceptable. We plan to follow up with the FBI and expect compliance with the subpoena.â€
This comes after the House Oversight Committee revealed a series of bank statements showing how the Biden family received $10 million in payments from foreign nationalsâ€™ companies while Joe Biden was Vice President.
â€œBiden familyÂ members and business associates created a web of over 20 companiesâ€”most were limited liability companies formed during Joe Bidenâ€™s vice presidency,â€ reads a memorandum.

The Committee has identified payments to Biden family members from foreign companies while Joe Biden served as Vice President and after he left public office.â€

title: French Tourists Beaten by Group of â€˜Teensâ€™ in NYC
text:
An older Frenchman and members of his family were ambushed by a group of â€˜teensâ€™ while on vacation in New York City last week, according to reports.
The disturbing incident unfolded at around 9 p.m. on Saturday evening in Manhattan.
Giles Viguier, 71, along with his wife, daughter, and son-in-law, were heading back to their hotel after dinner in Midtown when they were jumped by five male and female assailants.
â€œWe were walking back from the restaurant when a bunch of teenagers came from behind,â€ Viguier told the New York Daily News. 
â€œOne of the teens pushed me and I turned around to get him to stop and he punched me in the head and I went down.â€
When Viguierâ€™s daughter tried to defend him, she was also punched in the face.
Viguierâ€™s 29-year-old son-in-law, Michael Poret, said he was afraid to fight back because it might provoke a more severe attack.
â€œIâ€™ve seen the videos of what can happen in New York. In Paris, I would have taken them,â€ Poret said. 
â€œMy wife tried to defend her father and she got punched. She then pulled out her phone and started to record the group.â€
â€œThey wanted to keep hitting him until my wife started to film them,â€ he asserted.
The suspects fled the scene and were still on the loose as of Wednesday morning.
NYPD released an image of one of the attackers and requested that anyone with helpful information contact them.
French tourist, 71, punched in face, pushed to ground by teens in Midtown https://t.co/FjAuRWOezx pic.twitter.com/o7NpApqpq6

During the conference Flaherty was attempting to argue in favor of Proposal No. 8, which would have Berkshire Hathaway â€œrequire two separate people hold the office of chairman and office of CEO,â€ which NLPC said would help the company â€œbe less identified with Mr. Buffettâ€™s personal political activities.â€
Flaherty was halfway done with his speech condemning Buffett when he mentioned fellow philanthropist Bill Gatesâ€™ close association with Epstein, at which point the audience gasped and Buffett motioned for him to be removed. 
Speaking to The Daily Signal, Flaherty estimated it was his Epstein comment that really got him in trouble.
â€œI apparently touched the third rail of billionaire politics when I mentioned Jeffrey Epsteinâ€™s name,â€ FlahertyÂ said. â€œIâ€™ve been involved in shareholder activism for 19 years, and I have never before had my mic cut and I was never before arrested.â€Â 
â€œI was treated like any other criminal, fingerprinted, handcuffed,â€ Flaherty said of the arrest. â€œIâ€™ve always been courteous with decorum at the annual shareholder meetings. I didnâ€™t raise my voice. I was not disruptive.â€
The Signal revealed details behind Flahertyâ€™s arrest:
Two security officers then stood in front of Flaherty and told him that he would be arrested if he continued.Â 
Flaherty recalled responding that he would leave after finishing his statement. He said he didnâ€™t know at the time that his microphoneâ€™s audio had been cut.Â 
Next, an Omaha police officer told Flaherty that he was under arrest and escorted him from the meeting at CHI Health Center Arena. Police transported him to the Douglas County Correctional Center in Omaha, where he was searched, handcuffed, and charged with criminal trespass.
Read a transcript of the comments Flaherty delivered below, complete with interruptions, including the full statement he intended to deliver: 
I am Peter Flaherty, Chairman of the National Legal and Policy Center.
If we had an independent chair, the Company would be less identified with Mr. Buffettâ€™s political activities.
Heâ€™s donated more than $100 billion to the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation. As Bill Gates explained when the couple was still together, â€œalthough the foundation bears our names, basically half our resources have come from Warren Buffett.â€
If â€œwokeâ€ culture is a disease, then philanthropy is the virus.
The Gates Foundation bankrolls the teaching of Critical Race Theory around the country, including that math is inherently racist.
The Gates Foundation offers a Gender Identity Toolbox, which asserts that gender is the result of â€œsocially and culturally constructed ideas.â€
This is a lie. Gender is not a cultural construct. It is a genetic and biological fact.
[At this point, Flaherty tells a woman interrupting him, â€œYouâ€™re not gonna censor what I say maâ€™am. Iâ€™m very sorry. And Iâ€™ll appeal to the chair that I be allowed to continue.â€ Buffett allows him to continue, but tell him to keep in mind time restraints.]
We know how much Bill Gates cares about children. He met and traveled with Jeffrey EpsteinÂ MANYÂ timesÂ AFTERÂ Epstein was convicted of sex crimes.
[Audience gasps]
The Gates Foundation had a huge influence over the COVID response fiasco. Bill Gates defended Chinaâ€™s COVID policies and still discounts the possibility that the virus originated from a lab, even though U.S. intelligence agencies disagree.
The Gates Foundation may be the largest single donor to the â€œdark moneyâ€ machine known as Arabella Associates which funds causes like defunding the police that are making American cities unlivable.
Money goes, too, to groups conducting [Flaherty is cut off from speaking] threatening and vulgar protests at their homes of Supreme Court Justices.
Mr. Buffett has quietly funneled more than $4 billion to groups supporting abortion on demand through the Susan Thompson Buffett Foundation.
Thatâ€™s $4 billion, with a B. Advocacy disguised as philanthropy.
Bill Gates has lamented political polarization and even worried aloud about a civil war. But it is billionaires who are funding the most shrill and extreme activists who are tearing our country apart.
Ironically, Mr. Buffett has pointed out that corporate executives can make a lot of people mad when they insert themselves into controversy.
Anheuser-Busch is finding that out. It cannot renounce its Dylan Mulvaney transgender promotion because it is handcuffed by its longtime support for activists who would turn on them in a minute.
Anheuser-Busch gets a perfect grade on the Human Rights Campaign scorecard, as do Berkshire portfolio companies like Coca-Cola, Bank of America, and Apple.
Bank of America and Apple help bankroll this group, which wants biological men to compete in womenâ€™s sports.
Worse, it is currently pressuring state legislatures to allow sex change operations on children, and to keep their parents out of the decision.
Letâ€™s revisit Coca-Cola, which I discussed at last yearâ€™s meeting. CEO James Quincey, a British citizen, tried to kill Georgiaâ€™s voter integrity law in 2021 by making inaccurate and inflammatory statements about it.
Thatâ€™s the law that President Biden called â€œJim Crow 2.0,â€ and which prompted Major League Baseball to move the All-Star game out of Atlanta.
Mr. Buffett jumped on the bandwagon, too, by signing a statement by corporate leaders suggesting that Republicans seek to restrict ballot access based on race.
Two years later, we can now evaluate that accusation.
Last year, an election was held in Georgia. Turnout was record breaking. According to an independent poll, 99% of voters said they had â€œno problemâ€ casting ballots. 92% said the new law either had no impact on their ability to vote or made it easier.
James Quincey was wrong, and Mr. Buffett, so were you.

text:

In chat logs exposed by a whistleblower, a social media group called â€œThe Loudoun County Love Warriorsâ€ made up of several campaign volunteers, supporters, and staff for several Loudoun County elected officials plotted to get parents fired and even killed for speaking out against the school board.
â€œI was taken back when I received a phone call from the sheriffâ€™s department â€“ a deputy â€“ saying I was being threatened online,â€ Loudoun County resident Mark Winn told 7News.
Exclusive: A whistleblower sent @7NewsDC copies of violent threats made against people who have spoken at Loudoun County School Board meetings.The threats & plots to get people fired appear to be from people associated with several Loudoun County elected officials & candidates. pic.twitter.com/Kx6ARjJVr5

Winn said his quoting scripture during remarks to the school board triggered the group, who claimed it was â€œhate speech.â€
â€œThey threatened my life and my livelihood,â€ said Winn. â€œQuoting scripture in a public forum, that never has been, and never should be considered hate speech. When they threaten someoneâ€™s employment or threaten somebodyâ€™s life, or threaten their home, yeah thatâ€™s hate speech.â€
From 7News:
After Winn spoke at a school board meeting in December 2022, one person in the â€œLoudoun Love Warriorsâ€ said they wanted to find Winnâ€™s employer and hold the company accountable until he is fired. That same person and others wrote:
But the conversations became even more extreme, prompting the whistleblower to come forward with the chat logs.

title: Know Thy Enemy: Top 50 Players of the Censorship-Industrial Complex Revealed
text:
An in-depth report by journalist Matt Taibbi reveals the extent of a bureaucracy known as the Censorship Industrial Complex, a new system of control in the domain of â€œhybrid warfare.â€
Taibbi is one of the main publishers of the Twitter Files, which revealed how Twitter worked with a constellation of government, corporate, journalistic, and NGO entities to control narratives and information.
In a new report, Taibbi lists in great detail the Top 50 organizations that comprise the Censorship-Industrial Complex (CIC), which include intelligence agencies, top globalist institutions, corporations, far-left think tanks, and liberal â€œfact-checkers.â€
Specifically, the CIC is categorized into seven groups: Government entities, Foundations, Big Tech, For-Profit disinformation companies, Academic Initiatives, Think Tanks, â€œFact-Checkers,â€ and Non-Governmental Organizations.
Taibbi claimed the groundwork for the CIC was laid during the years-long Russia collusion hoax weaponized by the Deep State to destroy Donald Trump.
â€œThis is why the Trump-Russia scandal in the United States will likely be remembered as a crucial moment in 21st-century history, even though the investigation superficially ended a non-story, fake news in itself,â€ he wrote.
â€œWhat the Mueller investigation didnâ€™t accomplish in ousting Trump from office, it did accomplish in birthing a vast new public-private bureaucracy devoted to stopping â€˜mis-, dis-, and malinformation,â€™ while smoothing public acquiescence to the emergence of a spate of new government agencies with â€˜information warfareâ€™ missions.â€
He went on to say the social media â€œde-platformingâ€ of Infowars founder Alex Jones in 2018 was just the tip of the iceberg of the CIC system.
While the civilian population only in recent years began haggling over â€œde-platformingâ€ incidents involving figures like Alex Jones and Milo Yiannopoulos, government agencies had already long been advancing a new theory of international conflict, in which the informational landscape is more importantly understood as a battlefield than a forum for exchanging ideas. In this view, â€œspammyâ€ ads, â€œjunkâ€ news, and the sharing of work from â€œdisinformation agentsâ€ like Jones arenâ€™t inevitable features of a free Internet, but sorties in a new form of conflict called â€œhybrid warfare.â€Â 
Taibbi noted the CIC bills itself as a defense sector arm working for the good of the nation, but in reality itâ€™s a â€œmessaging systemâ€ meant to control the U.S. population.
The â€œCensorship-Industrial Complexâ€ is just the Military-Industrial Complex reborn for the â€œhybrid warfareâ€ age.
Much like the war industry, pleased to call itself the â€œdefenseâ€ sector, the â€œanti-disinformationâ€ complex markets itself as merely defensive, designed to fend off the hostile attacks of foreign cyber-adversaries who unlike us have â€œmilitary limitations.â€ The CIC, however, is neither wholly about defense, nor even mostly focused on foreign â€œdisinformation.â€ Itâ€™s become instead a relentless, unified messaging system aimed primarily at domestic populations, who are told that political discord at home aids the enemyâ€™s undeclared hybridÂ assault on democracy.Â 
He pointed out that these censorship and information control groups are fundamentally destroying democracy using â€œhybrid warfareâ€ techniques to control the flow of information.
Together, these groups are fast achieving what Eisenhower feared: the elimination of â€œbalanceâ€ between the democratic need for liberalizing laws and institutions, and the vigilance required for military preparation. Democratic society requires the nourishment of free debate, disagreement, and intellectual tension, but the groups below seek instead that â€œshared vocabularyâ€ to deploy on the hybrid battlefield. They propose to serve as the guardians of that â€œvocabulary,â€ which sounds very like the scenario Ike outlined in 1961, in which â€œpublic policy could itself become the captive of a scientific and technological elite.â€
Taibbi said his list tries to answer â€œa few basic questions about funding, organization type, history, and especially, methodologyâ€ for â€œreporters and researchers beginning their journey toward learning the scale and ambitionâ€ of the CIC.

The Democratic National Committee also has no plans to organize any primary debates despite candidates like Kennedy and Marianne Williamson challenging Joe Biden, essentially coronating the puppet president as the Democrat nominee for 2024.
Kennedy criticized the lack of primary debates as â€œconfirmationâ€ that the â€œsystem is rigged against them.â€

â€œThereâ€™s too many Americans who already think that the whole system is rigged against them. And this is confirmation of that. And I think thatâ€™s troubling.â€
Though Kennedy and Trump may have philosophical and governance differences, theyâ€™re both hostile to the Deep State and vilified by the media for their anti-establishment positions, which include ending military-industrial complex wars and promoting free speech.

title: AMLO Urges Biden to End USAID Meddling in Mexico
text:
Mexican President AndrÃ©s Manuel LÃ³pez Obrador, commonly referred to as AMLO, recently sent a letter to US President Joe Biden asking that he stop interference in his country by the United States Agency of International Development (USAID).
According to LÃ³pez Obrador, USAID is funding opposition parties and so-called â€˜non-government organizationsâ€™ opposed to his administration, including Mexicans Against Corruption and Impunity and Article 19.
â€œI would like to express briefly,â€ AMLO said in the letter, â€œthat for some time now, the United States government, in particular the United States Agency for International Development, has been financing organizations openly opposed to the legal and legitimate government that I represent, which is clearly an interventionist act, contrary to international law and the respect that should prevail among independent and sovereign states.â€
LÃ³pez Obrador also added in the letter that funding to those groups has increased recently. â€œ[A] few days ago it was announced that said agency [USAID] will increase the budget granted to organizations opposed to our government, as published in the official page of the State Department,â€ he wrote.
However, AMLO stopped short of saying that Biden is aware of the program, instead asking for his â€œvaluable interventionâ€ to end it.
He also said he considered not sending the letter, but did so as a matter of principle and in defense of his countryâ€™s sovereignty soÂ â€œfuture generations should not wonder why this type of violations against the nationâ€™s sovereignty were allowed.â€
Article 19, responded, saying that AMLOâ€™s comments amounted to â€œattacks against press freedom.â€
AMLO spoke about the letter at a May 3 news conference after being asked if he brought up the issue of the US Department of Defense spying on the Mexican military, including top officials like the Secretariat of the Navy and the Secretariat of National Defense.
LÃ³pez Obrador accused the US of spying at an April conference, claiming media in Mexico â€œare publishing information provided by the DEA [US Drug Enforcement Agency] and Pentagonâ€ that had been obtained illegally.
The letter to Biden was given to his national security adviser Elizabeth Sherwood-Randall, who was in Mexico on official business.
USAID has long been criticized for clandestinely undermining governments on behalf of the US intelligence community, particularly in Central and South America.
State Department documents and cables have revealed over the past decade that USAID has been involved in coups or attempted coups in Cuba, Bolivia, Venezuela and a number of other countries over the past two decades.
AMLO said during the earlier presser that he is not concerned about the alleged interventionism, explaining it loses its power once the people are made aware of its existence.
â€œIf we inform the people, there is no problem because we have nothing to hide. We have no complicity with anyone; we are not corrupt; we have moral authority,â€ LÃ³pez Obrador said. â€œWe are doing this, because, although it does not harm us, politically speaking, by revealing all this, the people become awareâ€”they understand better what we have been saying all this time, that these conservatives are traitors to the nation.â€
Biden and LÃ³pez Obrador spoke on the phone on Tuesday in a talk that focused on the growing border crisis as Title 42 nears its expiration. It is not known if AMLO brought up the issue of USAID to Biden during that talk.

title: Tucker Carlson Was Fired By Fox News as Part of Settlement with Dominion â€” Report
text:
Fox News fired Tucker Carlson as part of its settlement with Dominion Voting Systems, Axios is reporting.
A letter written by Carlsonâ€™s attorney Bryan Freedman claims Fox News employees and even â€œRupert Murdoch himselfâ€ are guilty of fraud and breach of contract for breaking promises to Carlson â€œintentionally and with reckless disregard for the truth.â€
From Axios: 
The lawyers accuse Fox executives â€” which two sources say are Dinh and Murdoch â€” of making â€œmaterial representations,â€ or promises, to Carlson that were intentionally broken, constituting fraud.
Notably, the letter alleges Fox broke an agreement with Carlson not to leak his private communications to the media and not to use Carlsonâ€™s private messages â€œto take any adverse employment action against him.â€
Multiple outlets haveÂ reportedÂ on Carlsonâ€™s redacted communications from pre-trial discovery documents and have suggested that they led to his ousting.
The letter also allegesÂ Fox broke promises not to settle with Dominion Voting Systems â€œin a way which would indicate wrongdoingâ€ on the part of Carlson and not to take any actions in a settlement that would harm Carlsonâ€™s reputation.
The letter claims he was told by a Fox board member he was fired as part of the networkâ€™s settlement with Dominion.
â€œCarlson was told by a member of the Fox board that he was taken off the air as part of the Dominion settlement, two sources briefed on a conversation told Axios,â€ the report states.
If that allegation is true, Fox breached its contract because it created â€œadditional terms of Carlsonâ€™s employment that were then broken by the company,â€ the lawyers argued.
â€œThese actions not only breached the covenant of good faith and fair dealing in the Agreement, but give rise to claims for breach of contract, and intentional and negligent misrepresentation,â€ the letter says.
Fox News and Dominion both denied Carlsonâ€™s firing had anything to do with the $787.5Â million lawsuit settlement.
Donald Trump, Jr. noted that if the report that Dominion talked Fox into firing Tucker is true, red states must move to ban Dominion from administering its elections.
â€œWhoa. If itâ€™s true that Dominion forced Fox to fire Tucker, every red state legislator in America should move to ban them from administering their elections. No company that makes such partisan, ideological demands can be trusted to run impartial ballot counting,â€ Trump tweeted Tuesday.
Whoa. If itâ€™s true that Dominion forced Fox to fire Tucker, every red state legislator in America should move to ban them from administering their elections. No company that makes such partisan, ideological demands can be trusted to run impartial ballot counting. https://t.co/dbTb9TSeL5
Carlson announced Tuesday that he would be launching a new version of his longtime show on Twitter.
Weâ€™re back. pic.twitter.com/sG5t9gr60O
This comes days after reports that Carlson was in talks with Twitter CEO Elon Musk to form a sort of media alliance to take on Fox News ahead of the 2024 election.

title: â€˜The Viewâ€™ Argues Subway Passengers Shouldâ€™ve Just Given Their Money to Serial Criminal Neely
text:
The panel of ABCâ€™s â€œThe Viewâ€ defended serial criminal Jordan Neelyâ€™s threats and extortion of New York City subway passengers preceding his untimely death, arguing the passengers should have just given him their money.
Co-host Sunny Hostin first demanded that Neelyâ€™s criminal history should not have been revealed to the public because that would be â€œre-victimizing this victim.â€
â€œThe reason he had so many mental health issues is because he saw the brutal murder of his mother at the age of 14. When he was recently arrested, rather than put him in jail, they actually â€” he pled guilty and he was sentenced to live at a Bronx treatment facility, take his medication, and stay clean for 15 months. Unfortunately, he left the place after 13 days,â€ Hostin said Tuesday.
â€œSo this is a troubled person who needed help. As prosecutors, when someone is a danger to society, you donâ€™t give them â€” you donâ€™t put them in a mental health facility, you put them in prison,â€ she said, ignoring the fact Neely was a serial criminal who was repeatedly released back into the public thanks to Democrat soft-on-crime policies.
Hostin castigated the passengers for not surrendering their money to a homeless Neely right away when he was harassing passengers on the subway.
â€œThis is what he was doing. He was shouting that he was hungry, that he was thirsty, and he had little to live for. Hungry, thirsty, and little to live for.Â Where was the humanity of anyone that was on that train?! I would have given him money! I would have tried to give him food! I would have tried to help!Â This is someone in need, in desperate need,â€ she said.
Hostin went on to excoriate Marine Daniel Penny, who put an aggressive Neely in a recovery position before he died on the F train.
â€œAnd I am ashamed that someone that was part of our armed forces decided to become a vigilante and kill him,â€Â she whined, as if Penny preemptively decided to confront Neely that day.
Hostin then called for the defunding of the New York police â€” despite the fact they werenâ€™t even involved in the killing of Neely.
â€œMay I make a quick suggestion? New York City has the highest police budget in our entire country. I think itâ€™s something like $5 billion.Â How about taking a billion dollars of that money, Whoopi, and doing what you did with Comic Relief, and get them the mental health services that they need?â€ she asked.
Pennyâ€™s lawyer released a statement Saturday explaining that his client never meant to harm Neely, but was compelled to subdue the mentally ill man when he â€œbegan aggressively threateningâ€ passengers.
Neely was a homeless Michael Jackson impersonator, with 42 prior arrests from 2013 and 2021, who lost consciousness during the struggle with Penny and was later pronounced dead at a hospital. Penny was taken into custody and released without charges.
â€œWe would first like to express, on behalf of Daniel Penny, our condolences to those close to Mr. Neely,â€ the law firm of Raiser and Kenniff, P.C. said in a statement Friday. â€œWhen Mr. Neely began aggressively threatening Daniel Penny and the other passengers, Daniel, with the help of others, acted to protect themselves, until help arrived.â€
â€œDaniel never intended to harm Mr. Neely and could not have foreseen his untimely death,â€ the statement said. â€œWe hope that out of this awful tragedy will come a new commitment by our elected officials to address the mental health crisis on our streets and subways.â€
George Floyd-esque BLM demonstrations sprang up in NYC and other cities to protest Neelyâ€™s untimely death last week and characterize it as a hate crime.
H/t Newsbusters

title: Wendyâ€™s Unveils Google-Powered AI Chatbot At Drive-Thru
text:
Wendyâ€™s is reportedly developing anÂ artificial intelligence chatbot powered by Googleâ€™s natural-language software designed to automate drive-thrus.Â 
The Wall Street JournalÂ spoke with Wendyâ€™s Chief Executive Todd Penegor, who said theÂ fast-food chainâ€™s chatbot would be rolled out in JuneÂ at a company-owned restaurant in Columbus, Ohio.Â 
The Wendyâ€™s drive-thru chatbot â€œwill be very conversational,â€Â Penegor explained. He said, â€œYou wonâ€™t know youâ€™re talking to anybody but an employee.â€Â 
Wendyâ€™s software engineers have been working with Google to build a large language model to understand words, popular expressions, and phrases in various dialects and accents when a customer orders. Itâ€™ll understand acronyms unique to Wendyâ€™s, like â€œJBCâ€ for a junior bacon cheeseburger.Â 

â€œGoogle Cloudâ€™s generative AI technology creates a huge opportunity for us to deliver a truly differentiated, faster, and frictionless experience for our customers, and allows our employees to continue focusing on making great food and building relationships with fans that keep them coming back time and again,â€ Penegor said in a separate conversation about the chatbot while speaking withÂ Gizmodo.Â 
WSJ said the drive-thru chatbot is programmed to upsell customers by asking if they want to combo the order or increase sizes. Once the order is completed, humans operating the kitchen will (which will one day beÂ replaced by robot chefs) prepare the food before being packaged up and stuffed into a bag for pickup at the window.Â 
Wendyâ€™s Chief Information Officer Kevin Vasconi told WSJ that the chatbotÂ â€œis probably on average betterâ€ than the companyâ€™s top customer service reps. He said the chatbotâ€™s goal is to improve service speed and consistency at drive-thrus. About 80% of all food orders are placed at the burger chainâ€™s drive-thrus.Â 
Besides Wendyâ€™s, we have outlined the move by other fast-food restaurants, like McDonaldâ€™s, to automate stores and replace humans:Â 
Thereâ€™s even been a push by McDonaldâ€™s to automate a restaurant entirely:Â 
The proliferation of automation in the fast food industry will only mean a tidal wave of layoffs is coming over this decade. According to market research firm IBISWorld, the US has more than 5 million workers.Â 
Recall a recent Goldman report (available toÂ pro subscribers in the usual place) that stated, â€œTwo-thirds of current jobs are exposed to some degree of AI automation,Â and that generative AI could substitute up to one-fourth of current work.Â Extrapolating our estimates globally suggests that generative AI could expose the equivalent of 300 million full-time jobs to automationâ€ as up to â€œtwo thirds of occupations could be partially automated by AI.â€
In other words, the robots are coming, and jobs will be lost.Â

title: Ex-Russian Space Boss Finds â€˜No Proofâ€™ Americans Landed On Moon In 1969
text:
Russiaâ€™s former head of the Roscosmos space agency, Dmitry Rogozin, said he went on a quest about a decade ago to find concrete proof that the Americans landed on the Moon in 1969. After finding little evidence, he questioned whether the Apollo 11 Mission reached the lunar surface.Â 
â€œAbout ten years ago, when I worked in the Government, I sent an official request to Roskosmos to provide me with documentary evidence of the Americansâ€™ stay on the moon, which at that time was still at the disposal of the federal agency,â€ Rogozin said in a post onÂ TelegramÂ on Sunday.Â 
He continued, â€œI was painfully embarrassed by the fact that the Soviet cosmonauts returning from multi-day expeditions could barely stand on their feet and underwent a long recovery after such flights, and the Americans crawled out of their lunar ships like cucumbers from the garden. â€œ
Rogozin claimed to have submitted multiple requests to Roscosmos for proof of NASAâ€™s 1969 Moon landing. He said the only evidence he received was a book that contained an account by Soviet Cosmonaut Aleksey Leonov about his conversation with the American astronauts and their discussions about the lunar mission.Â 

Rogozin continued in the post:Â 
In 2018, when I went to work at the state corporation Roskosmos, I continued to search for this evidence, but I didnâ€™t find anything there, except for the angry accusations of some of our fans of going to America at the expense of others, academicians, that I, they say, undermine the â€œsacred cooperation with NASA,â€ I also received one angry call from a high-ranking official accusing me of â€œaggravating the international situationâ€ with my doubts.
Yes, I did not undermine or aggravate anything, but only by virtue of my nature I tried to get to the bottom of the details and establish, at least for myself, the true state of affairs in the issue of exploration of the Moon by our competitors. It was not clear to me how the United States, at that level of technological development of the 60s of the last century, did what they still cannot do now?
Add Rogozin to the moon-landing denialism camp because how dare anyone question that the spacecraft with lessÂ computing power than even a modern USB-C chargerÂ could land astronauts on the Moon in 1969 â€” and astronauts have yet to return 54 years later.Â 
â€¦ still there are many questions.Â

title: FBI hacked American computers to â€˜fix Russian malwareâ€™
text:
The US federal government has claimed that it managed to disable a global computer network that was infected by â€˜Russianâ€™ malware, which had been in use for two decades. A court warrant allowed FBI agents to remotely access infected computers, which officials described as anÂ â€œinnovative use of legal authorities.â€
On Tuesday, the US Department of Justice revealed details of Operation MEDUSA, a joint effort by several US and foreign law enforcement and intelligence agencies that targeted a hacker group nicknamed â€˜Turlaâ€™.
US officials claimed that the group was linked to the Russian Federal Security Service (FSB), and had deployed a sophisticated malware toolkit dubbed â€˜Snakeâ€™. Compromised computers were used by the hackers to copy stolen files and deploy other cyberweapons, Washington claimed.
â€œThe Justice Department, together with our international partners, has dismantled a global network of malware-infected computers that the Russian government has used for nearly two decades to conduct cyber-espionage, including against our NATO allies,â€Â US Attorney General Merrick Garland said.

Operation MEDUSA involved the FBI remotely accessing infected computers and tricking Snake into self-destructing. The hacking was authorized by the Eastern District of New York and constitutedÂ â€œinnovative use of legal authorities,â€Â according to Matthew G. Olsen, who heads the DoJâ€™s National Security Division.
The US government did not say how many American computers it had accessed, but said it had notified owners of the operation.
Officials claimed that the FSB unit was operating out of the city of Ryazan and that the network under its control stretched across 50 nations. The Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) said human error on the part of the Russians had allowed US cybersecurity experts to identify the malware and develop a tool to counter it.
Washington described the outcome as a major victory for itself and its allies, stating that the network wasÂ â€œthe FSBâ€™s most sophisticated long-term cyberespionage malware implant.â€

title: Galactic bubbles are more complex than imagined, researchers say
text:
Astronomers have revealed new evidence about the properties of the giant bubbles of high-energy gas that extend far above and below the Milky Way galaxyâ€™s center.
In a study recently published inÂ Nature Astronomy, a team led by scientists at The Ohio State University was able to show that the shells of these structuresâ€”dubbed â€œeRosita bubblesâ€ after being found by the eRosita X-ray telescopeâ€”are more complex than previously thought.
Although they bear a striking similarity in shape to Fermi bubbles, eRosita bubbles are larger and more energetic than their counterparts. Known together as the â€œgalactic bubblesâ€ due to their size and location, they provide an exciting opportunity to study star formation history as well as reveal new clues about how the Milky Way came to be, said Anjali Gupta, lead author of the study and a former postdoctoral researcher at Ohio State who is now a professor of astronomy at Columbus State Community College.
These bubbles exist in the gas that surrounds galaxies, an area which is called the circumgalactic medium.
â€œOur goal was really to learn more about the circumgalactic medium, a place very important in understanding how our galaxy formed and evolved,â€ Gupta said. â€œA lot of the regions that we were studying happened to be in the region of the bubbles, so we wanted to see how different the bubbles are when compared to the regions which are away from the bubble.â€
Previous studies had assumed that these bubbles were heated by the shock of gas as it blows outward from the galaxy, but this paperâ€™s main findings suggest the temperature of the gas within the bubbles isnâ€™t significantly different from the area outside of it.
â€œWe were surprised to find that the temperature of the bubble region and out of the bubble region were the same,â€ said Gupta. Additionally, the study demonstrates that these bubbles are so bright because theyâ€™re filled with extremely dense gas, not because they are at hotter temperatures than the surrounding environment.
Gupta and Smita Mathur, co-author of the study and a professor of astronomy at Ohio State, did their analysis using observations made by the Suzaku satellite, a collaborative mission between NASA and the Japanese Aerospace Exploration Agency.
By analyzing 230 archival observations made between 2005 and 2014, researchers were able to characterize the diffuse emissionâ€”theÂ electromagnetic radiationÂ from very low density gasâ€”of the galactic bubbles, as well as the other hot gases that surround them.
Although the origin of these bubbles has been debated inÂ scientific literature, this study is the first that begins to settle it, said Mathur. As the team found an abundance of non-solar neon-oxygen and magnesium-oxygen ratios in the shells, their results strongly suggest that galactic bubbles were originally formed by nuclear star-forming activity, or the injection of energy byÂ massive starsÂ and other kinds of astrophysical phenomena, rather than through the activities of a supermassive black hole.
â€œOur data supports the theory that these bubbles are most likely formed due to intense star formation activity at the galactic center, as opposed to black hole activity occurring at the galactic center,â€ Mathur said. To further investigate the implications their discovery may have for other aspects of astronomy, the team hopes to use new data from other upcoming space missions to continue characterizing the properties of these bubbles, as well as work on novel ways to analyze the data they already have.
â€œScientists really do need to understand the formation of the bubble structure, so by using different techniques to better our models, weâ€™ll be able to better constrain the temperature and the emission measures that we are looking for,â€ said Gupta.
Other co-authors were Joshua Kingsbury and Sanskriti Das of Ohio State and Yair Krongold of the National Autonomous University of Mexico.

The chart he posted along with those comments shows Biden having created close to 500,000 jobs on average per month since he took office.
It shows other Presidents job creation stats, going back to Reagan, all way lower than Bidenâ€™s.
Community Notes soon took over the post, however, with readers pointing out that Biden has not created significantly more jobs than the other Presidents, and the chart merely shows the recovery of jobs after the COVID pandemic and lockdowns, which happened under Trump.
This is what happens when you invest in America.We have more work to do â€“ but this is real progress. pic.twitter.com/Pur91mu3Pf

The Community Notes featureÂ works by allowing all Twitter users to collaboratively add â€˜contextâ€™ to posts. â€œIf enough contributors from different points of view rate that note as helpful, the note will be publicly shown on a Tweet,â€ the platform states.
The system significantly reduces the risk of any partisan sources influencing the fact checks, as is apparent on other platforms such asÂ FacebookÂ whereÂ clearly non-independent actorsÂ areÂ influencing content.
As we highlighted last week, Elon Musk touted the system, declaring that â€œEnding censorship in guise of virtue, handing control of the narrative to the people and actually accurate fact-checking are essential goals.â€

title: God Help Us: Kamala Harris to Run AI Taskforce
text:
US Vice President Kamala Harris has been appointed to head a new artificial intelligence initiative in partnership with leading companies in the field, the White House announced in a press release on Thursday.
Harris and other senior officials in the administration of President Joe Biden will meet with the CEOs of Alphabet, Anthropic, Microsoft, and OpenAI to remind them of theirÂ â€œresponsibility to make sure their products are safe before they are deployed or made public.â€Â  Â 
The meeting is intended to keep the companies on track towardÂ â€œdriving responsible, trustworthy and ethical innovation with safeguards that mitigate risks and potential harms to individuals and our society,â€Â according to the White House, which referenced recent executive orders and official statements reminding tech companies that their products were subject to civil rights law and other protections against unlawful discrimination. Â 
The four companies, along with Hugging Face, NVIDIA, and Stability AI, will also submit to a public evaluation of their capabilities by thousands of industry experts and other curious members of the public at DEFCON 31, the Las Vegas hacking convention that has repeatedly put the insecurity of the USâ€™ voting machines on display by giving children a chance to hack them.
The White House also announced the creation of seven new National AI Research Institutes focusing on climate, agriculture, energy, public health, education, and cybersecurity, explaining the new institutes wouldÂ â€œsupport the development of a diverse AI workforceâ€Â with $140 million in funding from the National Science Foundation.Â 
The administration is also giving the public the chance to weigh in on government AI policy starting this summer, according to the press release. Â 
Tasked with stemming the flow of migrants over the USâ€™ southern border upon taking office in 2021, Harris instead presided over a record amount of illegal immigration, earning her the lowest approval rating of any modern US vice president. Last year, she was assigned with developing a blueprint for fightingÂ â€œdisinformation,â€Â harassment and abuse online despite having no experience in the technology sector. Â 
While hundreds of experts in the AI field have called for a moratorium on, or at least a dramatic slowdown of, AI development until internationally agreed-upon safety measures can be put in place, the US has thus far shied away from issuing any strong statements about the technology. Last month, Biden met with his Council of Advisors on Science and Technology to discuss theÂ â€œrisks and opportunitiesâ€Â in the field but declined to address the expertsâ€™ warnings while admitting AIÂ â€œcould beâ€Â dangerous.

title: COVID â€˜Vaccinesâ€™ Linked to Untreatable Eyeball Clots, Study Reveals
text:
The experimental COVID mRNAÂ injectionsÂ are linked to retinal vascular occlusion, with vaccinated individuals showing a â€œsignificantlyâ€ greater risk of developing blood clots than unvaccinated individuals, according to a massive new study.
The research, published this week in scientific journal Nature, explained that of the 7 million people selected for the study, 745,041 vaccinated and 3.8 million unvaccinated subjects were left to compare after controlling for confounding variables like medications and contraceptives.
The results were startling.
â€œWe demonstrated a higher risk and incidence rate of retinal vascular occlusion following COVID-19 vaccination, after adjusting for potential confounding factors,â€ the researchers wrote. â€œThe risk of retinal vascular occlusion, except for CRAO, has been promptly observed in individuals receiving vaccines against SARS-CoV-2. The risk factors for retinal vascular occlusion include diabetes, hypertension, obesity, coronary artery disease, and stroke.â€
In summary, the results found that â€œtwo years after vaccination, the chances of all subtypesâ€¦ of retinal vascular occlusion increased significantly in the vaccinated cohort.â€
â€œThe overall risk of retinal vascular occlusion in the vaccinated cohort was 2.19 times higher than that in the unvaccinated cohort at 2 years,â€ theÂ NatureÂ paper concluded, adding â€œno disparity was detected between brand and dose of vaccines.â€
Despite the clear correlation, the study claimed that â€œ[a]dditional research is required to draw a solid conclusion regarding the association between retinal vascular occlusion and COVID-19 vaccines.â€
Add this major study to the list of reasons to avoid the experimental mRNA shot masqueraded by the government and Big Pharma as â€œvaccines.â€

title: Study of Uranusâ€™ large moons shows four may hold water
text:
Re-analysis of data from NASAâ€™s Voyager spacecraft, along with new computer modeling, has led NASA scientists to conclude that four of Uranusâ€™ largest moons likely contain an ocean layer between their cores and icy crusts. 
Their study is the first to detail the evolution of the interior makeup and structure of all five large moons: Ariel, Umbriel, Titania, Oberon, and Miranda. The work suggests four of the moons hold oceans that could be dozens of miles deep.
In all, at least 27 moons circle Uranus, with the four largest ranging from Ariel, at 720 miles (1,160 kilometers) across, to Titania, which is 980 miles (1,580 kilometers) across. Scientists have long thought that Titania, given its size, would be most likely to retain internal heat, caused by radioactive decay. The other moons had previously been widely considered too small to retain the heat necessary to keep an internal ocean from freezing, especially because heating created by the gravitational pull of Uranus is only a minor source of heat.
The National Academiesâ€™ 2023 Planetary Science and Astrobiology Decadal Survey prioritized exploring Uranus. In preparation for such a mission, planetary scientists are focusing on the ice giant to bolster their knowledge about the mysterious Uranus system. Published in theÂ Journal of Geophysical Research: Planets, the new work could inform how a future mission might investigate the moons, but the paper also has implications that go beyond Uranus, said lead author Julie Castillo-Rogez of NASAâ€™s Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Southern California.
â€œWhen it comes to small bodiesâ€”dwarf planets and moonsâ€”planetary scientists previously have found evidence of oceans in several unlikely places, including theÂ dwarf planetsÂ Ceres and Pluto, and Saturnâ€™s moon Mimas,â€ she said. â€œSo there are mechanisms at play that we donâ€™t fully understand. This paper investigates what those could be and how they are relevant to the many bodies in the solar system that could be rich in water but have limited internal heat.â€
The study revisited findings from NASAâ€™s Voyager 2 flybys of Uranus in the 1980s and from ground-based observations. The authors built computer models infused with additional findings from NASAâ€™s Galileo, Cassini, Dawn, and New Horizons (each of which discovered ocean worlds), including insights into the chemistry and the geology of Saturnâ€™s moon Enceladus, Pluto and its moon Charon, and Ceresâ€”all icy bodies around the same size as the Uranian moons.
The researchers used that modeling to gauge how porous the Uranian moonsâ€™ surfaces are, finding that theyâ€™re likely insulated enough to retain the internal heat that would be needed to host an ocean. In addition, they found what could be a potential heat source in the moonsâ€™ rocky mantles, which release hot liquid, and would help an ocean maintain a warm environmentâ€”a scenario that is especially likely for Titania and Oberon, where the oceans may even be warm enough to potentially support habitability.
By investigating the composition of the oceans, scientists can learn about materials that might be found on the moonsâ€™ icy surfaces as well, depending on whether substances underneath were pushed up from below by geological activity. There isÂ evidence from telescopesÂ that at least one of the moons, Ariel, has material that flowed onto its surface, perhaps from icy volcanoes, relatively recently.
In fact, Miranda, the innermost and fifth largest moon, also hosts surface features that appear to be of recent origin, suggesting it may have held enough heat to maintain an ocean at some point. The recent thermal modeling found that Miranda is unlikely to have hosted water for long: It loses heat too quickly and is probably frozen now.
But internal heat wouldnâ€™t be the only factor contributing to a moonâ€™s subsurface ocean. A key finding in the study suggests that chlorides, as well as ammonia, are likely abundant in the oceans of the icy giantâ€™s largest moons. Ammonia has been long known to act as antifreeze. In addition, the modeling suggests that salts likely present in the water would be another source of antifreeze, maintaining the bodiesâ€™ internal oceans.
Of course, there still are a lot of questions about the large moons of Uranus, Castillo-Rogez said, adding that there is plenty more work to be done: â€œWe need to develop new models for different assumptions on the origin of the moons in order to guide planning for future observations.â€
Digging into what lies beneath and on the surfaces of these moons will help scientists and engineers choose the best science instruments to survey them. For instance, determining that ammonia and chlorides may be present means that spectrometers, which detect compounds by their reflected light, would need to use aÂ wavelength rangeÂ that covers both kinds of compounds.
Likewise, they can use that knowledge to design instruments that can probe the deep interior for liquid. Searching for electrical currents that contribute to a moonâ€™s magnetic field is generally the best way to find aÂ deep ocean, as Galileo mission scientists did at Jupiterâ€™sÂ moonÂ Europa. However, the cold water in the interior oceans of moons such as Ariel and Umbriel could make the oceans less able to carry these electrical currents and would present a new kind of challenge for scientists working to figure out what lies beneath.

title: A Credit Crunch Is Inevitable
text:
Federal ReserveÂ data shows $98 billion of deposits left the banking system in the week after the Silicon Valley Bank collapse. 
Most of the money went to money-market funds, as theÂ BloombergÂ data shows that assets in this class rose by $121 billion in the same period. The data shows the challenges of the banking system in the middle of a confidence crisis.
However, as many analysts point out, this is not necessarily the main factor that dictates the risk of a credit crunch. Deposit flight is certainly an important risk. Many regional banks will have to cut lending to families and businesses as deposits shrink, but in the United States bank loans are less than 19 percent of corporate credit according to the IMF, while in the euro area it is more than 80 percent. What will generate a credit crunch is the destruction of capital in the asset base of most lenders.
The slump in mark-to-market valuations of all asset classes from loans to investments is what will ultimately drive an inevitable credit contraction.
Credit standards have tightened significantly already, and the credit impulse of the economy, both in the US and euro area, has deteriorated rapidly, according to the respective Bloomberg indices. Both are below the March 2021 low.
We must remember that credit standardsâ€™ tightening was already a reality before the Silicon Valley Bank demise. But the reality check of capital destruction in the financial systemâ€™s asset base is far from done.
Start-ups will most likely see the most severe crunch in financing as the tech bubble burst adds to the asset base capital destruction in private equity and venture capital firms, who have delayed all they could the required write-downs and face a sobering reality check. Our internal estimate of capital destruction in the asset base of banks and private equity firms is between a 15 to 25 percent wipeout, which is consistent with the average decline in market value over the October 2021â€“March 2023 period.
Real estate investments all over the US and Europe require a significant reevaluation now that real estate has underperformed the market for eighteen months, according to Morgan Stanley. The optimistic valuations of real estate and corporate investments in banksâ€™ balance sheets will require a significant analysis and subsequent write-off that leads to much tighter credit standards and stringent investment conditions.
Capital destruction tends to be forgotten in a world used to constant central bank easing, but it is likely to be the main source of strangling of credit to families and businesses as banks and private equity firms deal with the loss of value and weakening earnings and cash flow of investments made at elevated valuations and unreasonable prices. The main challenge this time is that capital destruction is happening in almost every part of the lendersâ€™ asset base, from the allegedly low-risk part, sovereign bond portfolios, to the aggressively priced investments in volatile businesses and bull-market valuations of corporate and venture capital investments. The profitable asset part of banks will likely require important provisions for nonperforming loans, a subject that was raised by the Federal Reserve and the ECB months before the banking crisis. Furthermore, as governments will blame the recent collapses on lack of regulation again, it is extremely likely that new rules will be imposed demanding banks to book large provisions recognizing losses on the loan book ahead of time.
Even if we assume a modest impact on banksâ€™ balance sheets, the combination of higher rates, declining optimism about the economy and the slump in equity, private investments and bond valuations is going to inevitably lead to a massive crunch in access to credit and financing. It is more than banks. The crunch will come from private direct middle market loans, a decline in high-yield bond demand, while institutional leveraged loans may fall as access to leverage is more expensive and challenging and investment grade bonds may likely continue to see strong demand but at higher costs. The question is not when there will be a credit crunch, but how large and for how long. Considering the size of the famous â€œbubble of everything â€œand its slow implosion, it may last for a couple of years even with a central bank pivot, because by now a reverse in monetary policy may only zombify the financial system.

title: T-Mobile Shutters â€œFlagshipâ€ San Fran Store as Mass Exodus Escalates
text:
T-Mobile has joined the increasing number of businesses that have closed up shop in downtown San Francisco. This is due to the progressive city leadershipâ€™s inability to restore law and order amid skyrocketing crime.Â 
T-Mobileâ€™s 17,000 square feet flagship store in Union Square is now vacant, as theÂ San Francisco Business TimesÂ first reported.Â 
â€œWe recently reshaped our retail strategy,â€ a spokesperson for T-Mobile toldÂ SFGATEÂ via email in response to a question about the departure.Â 
The spokesperson did not provide details about the date of the closure. However, an employee from T-Mobileâ€™s Mission Street location confirmed the closure took place in April.Â 
News of the T-Mobile closure comes after Nordstrom Rack on Market Street andÂ Nordstrom inside Westfield MallÂ are set to close their doors this summer.Â 
A spokesperson for Westfield told SFGATE thatÂ â€œa growing number of retailers and businesses are leaving the area due to the unsafe conditions for customers, retailers, and employees, coupled with the fact that these significant issues are preventing an economic recovery of the area.â€Â 
Other stores that have recently vacated or announced leaving the downtown district include Office Depot, The Container Store, Anthropologie,Â Whole Foods, Disney Store, Armani Exchange, CB2, and Saks Off 5th.Â 
Since 2020, twenty retailers have closed their stores in San Franciscoâ€™s Union Square, as the San Francisco Standard recently reported. All stores have pointed to theft. In other areas,Â CVS and Walgreens have shuttered stores.Â 
The retail departures are another blow for the city as the tech downturn worsens, coupled with theÂ regional banking crisis, which has spread intoÂ commercial real estate, mainly the office space segment.Â 
The gold-standard measure of office occupancy trends is the card-swipe data provided by Kastle Systems. The average office occupancy in San Fran is around 45%, still well off the highs from pre-pandemic levels.
This means that workers have been slow to return to the office,Â which is evident as Salesforce, Meta Platforms, and other tech companies are hemorrhaging office space, hurting the local economy.Â 
Last week, Democratic Mayor London Breed admitted, â€œTheÂ challenges facing downtownÂ require us to imagine what is possible and create the foundation for a stronger, more resilient future.â€ She suggested that there are ways to â€œfill our empty buildingsâ€ with residential housing.Â 
Other stores may be set to leave the crime-ridden city as progressive dreams of a â€˜utopiaâ€™ have backfired. Now there is aÂ two-mile-long encampmentÂ just north of The Bay Area.Â Â

title: Wendyâ€™s Unveils Google-Powered AI Chatbot At Drive-Thru
text:
Wendyâ€™s is reportedly developing anÂ artificial intelligence chatbot powered by Googleâ€™s natural-language software designed to automate drive-thrus.Â 
The Wall Street JournalÂ spoke with Wendyâ€™s Chief Executive Todd Penegor, who said theÂ fast-food chainâ€™s chatbot would be rolled out in JuneÂ at a company-owned restaurant in Columbus, Ohio.Â 
The Wendyâ€™s drive-thru chatbot â€œwill be very conversational,â€Â Penegor explained. He said, â€œYou wonâ€™t know youâ€™re talking to anybody but an employee.â€Â 
Wendyâ€™s software engineers have been working with Google to build a large language model to understand words, popular expressions, and phrases in various dialects and accents when a customer orders. Itâ€™ll understand acronyms unique to Wendyâ€™s, like â€œJBCâ€ for a junior bacon cheeseburger.Â 

â€œGoogle Cloudâ€™s generative AI technology creates a huge opportunity for us to deliver a truly differentiated, faster, and frictionless experience for our customers, and allows our employees to continue focusing on making great food and building relationships with fans that keep them coming back time and again,â€ Penegor said in a separate conversation about the chatbot while speaking withÂ Gizmodo.Â 
WSJ said the drive-thru chatbot is programmed to upsell customers by asking if they want to combo the order or increase sizes. Once the order is completed, humans operating the kitchen will (which will one day beÂ replaced by robot chefs) prepare the food before being packaged up and stuffed into a bag for pickup at the window.Â 
Wendyâ€™s Chief Information Officer Kevin Vasconi told WSJ that the chatbotÂ â€œis probably on average betterâ€ than the companyâ€™s top customer service reps. He said the chatbotâ€™s goal is to improve service speed and consistency at drive-thrus. About 80% of all food orders are placed at the burger chainâ€™s drive-thrus.Â 
Besides Wendyâ€™s, we have outlined the move by other fast-food restaurants, like McDonaldâ€™s, to automate stores and replace humans:Â 
Thereâ€™s even been a push by McDonaldâ€™s to automate a restaurant entirely:Â 
The proliferation of automation in the fast food industry will only mean a tidal wave of layoffs is coming over this decade. According to market research firm IBISWorld, the US has more than 5 million workers.Â 
Recall a recent Goldman report (available toÂ pro subscribers in the usual place) that stated, â€œTwo-thirds of current jobs are exposed to some degree of AI automation,Â and that generative AI could substitute up to one-fourth of current work.Â Extrapolating our estimates globally suggests that generative AI could expose the equivalent of 300 million full-time jobs to automationâ€ as up to â€œtwo thirds of occupations could be partially automated by AI.â€
In other words, the robots are coming, and jobs will be lost.Â

title: Is There an Optimum Growth Rate of Money?
text:
It is widely held that a growing economy requires a growing money stock because economic growth increases demand for money. Many economists also believe that failing to accommodate the increase in the demand for money leads to a decline in consumer prices. This could destabilize the economy and produce an economic recession or even a depression.
Some economists who follow Milton Friedmanâ€”also known as monetaristsâ€”want the central bank to target the money supply growth rate to a fixed percentage. They hold that if this percentage is maintained over a prolonged period, it will create economic stability.
The idea that money must grow to support economic growth implies that money sustains economic activity. However, moneyâ€™s main job is to be a medium of exchange, not sustain economic activity. Instead, economic sustenance is provided by saved consumer goods.
As for money, many different goods have served as a medium of exchange. Ludwig von MisesÂ wroteÂ that over time â€œthere would be an inevitable tendency for the less marketable of the series of goods used as media of exchange to be one by one rejected until at last only a single commodity remained, which was universally employed as a medium of exchange; in a word, money.â€
Over thousands of years, people have settled on gold as their preferred medium of exchange. Most economists, while accepting this historical evolution, doubt that gold can serve as money in a modern economy because of goldâ€™s limited supply.
This, in turn, risks destabilizing the economy. Hence, most economists, even those who express support toward the idea of a free market, believe the government must control the money supply.
Demand for money is the demand for moneyâ€™s purchasing power. After all, they donâ€™t want more money for its own sake; they want more purchasing power. In a free market, supply and demand determine the price of money. If there is less money its exchange value will increase, and the exchange value will fall when there is more money, everything else being equal.
Within a free market, there cannot be â€œtoo littleâ€ or â€œtoo muchâ€ money. If the market is allowed to clear, no shortage or surplus of money can emerge. Once the market has chosen a particular commodity as money, the stock of this commodity will always be sufficient to secure what money provides. Hence, in a free market, the whole idea of an optimum growth rate of money is absurd.
According toÂ Mises, â€œThe services which money renders can be neither improved nor repaired by changing the supply of money.Â .Â .Â . The quantity of money available in the whole economy is always sufficient to secure for everybody all that money does and can do.â€
Yet, even if we were to agree that the gold standard was better than the present monetary system, surely we must be practical and in tune with the current reality. In todayâ€™s world, we have central banks and are not on the gold standard. Given these facts, what then should be the correct money supply growth rate?
Originally, paper money was not regarded as money but as a representation of gold. Paper certificates represented claims on the gold stored with the banks. The holders of paper certificates could convert them into gold, but because individuals found it more convenient to use paper certificates, these certificates came to be regarded as money.
Paper certificates accepted as a medium of exchange open the way for fraud. Banks could now be tempted to boost their profits by lending certificates not covered by gold. In a free-market economy, a bank that overissues paper certificates will quickly find that the exchange value of its certificates will decline. To protect their purchasing power, holders of the overissued certificates would likely attempt to convert them back to gold.
If all of them were to demand gold back at the same time, this would bankrupt the bank. In a free, competitive market, the threat of bankruptcy would restrain banks from issuing paper certificates unbacked by gold. This means that in a free-market economy, paper money cannot assume a â€œlife of its ownâ€ and become independent of commodity money.
The government, however, can bypass the free-market discipline. It can decree that overissued banks need not redeem paper certificates into gold. Once banks are not obliged to redeem paper certificates into gold, opportunities for large profits create incentives to pursue an unrestrained expansion of the supply ofÂ paper certificates.
This uncontrolled expansion of paper certificates increases the likelihood of setting off price increases that could break down a market economy. To prevent such a breakdown, the supply of paper money must be managed, which can be done by establishing a monopoly central bank that manages the supply of paper money.
To assert its authority, the central bank introduces paper certificates which replace the bank certificates. The central bankâ€™s certificate purchasing power is established because paper certificates are exchanged for the central bankâ€™s money at a fixed rate. The central bank paper certificates are fully backed by banksâ€™ certificates, which have the historical link to gold.
The central bankâ€™s paper certificates, which are legal tender, also serve as reserve assets for banks. This enables the central bank to set a limit on the credit expansion by the banking system by setting regulatory ratios of reserves to demand deposits.
It would then appear that the central bank could manage and stabilize the monetary system, but that is not true. The present paper monetary system emerged because central authorities made it legal for the overissued banks not to redeem paper certificates into gold.
To manage the system, the central bank must constantly generate money out of nothing to prevent banks from bankrupting each other during the clearance of checks. This leads to persistent declines in the moneyâ€™s purchasing power, which destabilizes the entire monetary system.
Even Milton Friedmanâ€™s scheme to fix the money growth rate at a given percentage will not eliminate the problem. A fixed percentage growth is still money growth, which leads to the exchange of nothing for something, setting off boom-bust cycles.
What about keeping the current stock of paper money unchanged? Would that not do the trick? An unchanged money stock will cause an almost immediate breakdown of the present monetary system. The present system survives because the central bank, by means of monetary injections, prevents the fractional reserve banks from going bankrupt.
Central banks must always resort to large monetary injections during political or economic shocks. How long the central bank can keep the present system going depends upon the state of savings. If savings are growing, the central bank can keep the system alive.
Once savings begin to stagnate or even shrink, no amount of monetary pumping can prevent the system from imploding.
Because the present monetary system is fundamentally unstable, there cannot be a â€œcorrectâ€ money supply growth rate. The present monetary system emerged because central authorities allowed the practice of issuing banknotes not covered by gold. To sustain such a system, the central bank was introduced. By means of ongoing monetary management, the central bankâ€™s job is to prevent banks from bankrupting each other during the clearance of checks. Whether the central bank injects money in accordance with economic activity or fixes the money supply growth rate, it continuously destabilizes the system.
subject: News

title: Peter Schiff: The US Is in a Financial Crisis Worse than â€™08
text:
During hisÂ post-FOMC meeting press conference, Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell insisted that the US banking system is resilient and sound. He said this despiteÂ the failure of First Republic BankÂ just days before the Fed meeting. Peter Schiff appeared on theÂ Claman CountdownÂ on Fox News and argued that Powell and others are wrong. He said the US economy is in a financial crisis worse than in 2008.
Andy Brenner, head of international fixed income at National Alliance Securities, also appeared in the segment. He started things off by saying problems in the banking sector are â€œnot over by a longshot.â€
Liz Claman asked Peter why the Fed raised rates another 25 basis points despite the shakiness in the banking sector. Peter said they did it because thatâ€™s exactly what the market expected.
â€œThatâ€™s what the Fed does â€” what the markets expect.â€
But Peter said the move by the Fed isnâ€™t going to do anything to bring inflation down.
â€œThe elephant in the room with respect to inflation is the fiscal policy â€“ the debt, not the ceiling â€“ but the fact that weâ€™re running these massive deficits. But until the Federal government reduces spending, these quarter-point increases are going to be completely ineffective.â€
Peter said the problem is Powell refuses to call Congress out and mention that the driving force behind all of the inflation is reckless government spending.
â€œAnd as long as the government keeps spending, inflation is going to get worse, and so is the current financial crisis. Nobody wants to admit weâ€™re in a financial crisis. Itâ€™s worse than the one we had in 2008. Itâ€™s just getting started. Ultimately, the Fed is going to cut. But itâ€™s going to cut as inflation is accelerating.â€
Liz played a clip of Jerome Powell saying that the Fed is now paying particular attention to tightening credit conditions and its impact on bank lending. She also pointed out that Peter has previously said thatÂ the Fed has screwed up everything that is a function of interest rates. So how will these things specifically impact the economy moving forward? Peter said it was going to affect banks in particular.
â€œI have warned for years that the banks could start collapsing for the precise reason that theyâ€™re collapsing now. The Fed kept interest rates at zero for so long. Thatâ€™s what allowed these financial institutions to load up on overpriced, low-yielding Treasuries, mortgage-backed securities, and other loans. Plus, US government auditors from the FDIC encouraged the banks to buy these long-term Treasuries and mortgage-backed securities because they gave them favorable accounting treatment. The banks didnâ€™t have to mark them to market as long as they could pretend they would hold them to maturity. So, the whole house of cards was erected by the Fed and the US government. And now itâ€™s collapsing, and theyâ€™re acting like they have nothing to do with it. Theyâ€™re trying to figure out how to put out a fire that they lit. And of course, theyâ€™re not putting out the fire. Theyâ€™re pouring gasoline on it.â€
Brenner noted that there are about $1.9 trillion in unrealized losses on bank books. Liz pointed out that a study from Stanford and Columbia Universities foundÂ 186 US banks are in distress. Brenner reiterated, â€œNo question, the banking crisis is not over by a longshot.â€
Peter said everybody who has debt is going to feel the pain of rising interest rates.
â€œIt makes that debt hard to service. And of course, thereâ€™s a lot of debt that is still low because it hasnâ€™t matured yet. A lot of corporations, a lot of people in the real estate market, particularly commercial real estate, borrowed money two, three, four, five years ago at a really low rate. And the higher rates are when those loans mature, itâ€™s going to be that much harder for them to get the financing to roll them over. And then you have the prospect of very disorderly bankruptcies throughout the economy.â€
